attributes.title: Exceptionalism and Exemptionalism: Framing Public Opinion on the International Criminal Court

q1.value: Exceptionalism and Exemptionalism: Framing Public Opinion on the International Criminal Court

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The United States is the last of its peers yet to join the International Criminal Court (ICC). Scholars and policy makers alike have concluded that the U.S. is unlikely to join international organizations, and courts in particular, unless it can exercise significant control over them. How- ever recent public opinion polls report that awareness of the ICC among U.S. adults is steadily increasing and that this increasing awareness is coupled with increasing support of the Court, including membership. In this paper, I seek to clarify if there is a discrepancy between the public’s desires and the policy positions of its leaders. Specifically, I seek to identify if the American public is truly exceptionalist—that is, motivated by U.S. leadership in international human rights—or, given competing issue frames, if the public is actually exemptionalist, like its leaders—that is, motivated by self-interest and exclusion from the international human rights regime. I propose an experimental approach, utilizing competing exceptionalist and exemption- alist frames, to clarify this puzzle. Prior scholarship submits that framing issues in ways that resonate with core American values catalyzes costly moral action in foreign policy. I theorize that, given competing frames, Americans will be more exceptionalist than exemptionalist.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 Information Participants who receive information about the ICC, namely its goals and jurisdiction, will be more likely to support the U.S. joining the ICC than those who receive no prior information. Hypothesis 2 American Exemptionalism Participants who receive an exemptionalism frame, namely possible prosecution of an American soldier alleged to have committed war crimes, as well as discussion of sovereignty/jurisdiction concerns, will be less likely to support the U.S. joining the ICC than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 3 American Exceptionalism Participants who receive an American exceptionalism cue, concerning the United States’ historical support of international courts and tribunals, as well as discussion of the importance of future leadership, will be more likely to support the U.S. joining the ICC than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 4 The Neutralizing Effect of Competitive Frames Participants who receive competing exemptionalist and exceptionalist cues will be neither more likely nor less likely to support the ICC than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 5 The Moderating Effect of Competitive Frames Participants who receive competing exemptionalist and exceptionalist frames will be less exemption- alist and exceptionalist than those exposed to only a single frame, but more exempetionalist and exceptionalist than those who receive the control treatment. Hypothesis 6 Exceptionalism > Excemptionalism Participants who receive competing exemptionalist and exceptionalist cues will be more likely to support the ICC than participants who receive a single frame or who receive the control treatment.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, I designed a survey experiment, conducted using Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk). I randomly assign 1,000 U.S. adult participants to five experimental conditions. To ensure that (at least) half of the participants have a shared definition and basic understanding of the ICC, I provide background information to half of the respondents before presenting the main treatment frames. Vignette 1 provides the American exemptionalism cue, by implicating an American soldier in abuses subject to investigation and prosecution by the ICC and providing a rationale for non-membership in the ICC. If participants believe the U.S. should become a member of the ICC to a lesser degree than the control group, this will be consistent with Hypothesis 2. Vignette 2 provides the American exceptionalism cue by noting the U.S.’s historical role in supporting international criminal tribunals, and suggesting the U.S.’s importance to the ICC and human rights and liberal values broadly conceived.5 If participants believe that the U.S. should become a member of the ICC to a greater degree than the control group, this will be consistent with Hypothesis 3. Vignette 3 provides the competing frames of American exemptionalism and American excep- tionalism (randomized ordering of Vignettes 1 and 2). If participants believe that the U.S. should become a member of the ICC to neither a greater nor lesser degree than the control group, this will be consistent with Hypothesis 4. If participants believe that the U.S. should become a member of the ICC to a greater degree than the control group but to a lesser degree than participants exposed to a single frame, this will be consistent with Hypothesis 5. Finally, if participants believe that the U.S. should become a member of the ICC to a greater degree than the control group and participants exposed to a single frame, this will be consistent with Hypothesis 6. To gauge the basis upon which each subject justifies his/her support of/opposition to U.S. ICC membership, I ask participants which factor helped them respond to the main DV (i.e., “Do you believe the United States should become a member of the Court?”) for cross-examination. I do this via a multiple-choice question and an open-ended item. In addition, I introduce two attitudinal indicators. The first attitudinal indicator captures participants’ belief that the U.S. should (or should not) provide financial support to the ICC, regardless of membership. The second attitudinal indicator captures participants’ reported likelihood of calling their U.S. Senator about whether or not the U.S. should join the ICC. Since these are only stated preferences, I further introduce two behavioral indicators to gauge participants’ degree of commitment to their response. The first behavioral indicator requires participants to identify their willingness to give a portion of their MTurk earnings from this study to the ICC’s Trust Fund for Victims (TFV) which provides physical, psychological, and financial support to victims of genocide, crimes of humanity and war crimes and their families. The inclusion of this indicator reveals respondents’ preferences and the degree to which they are willing to engage in moral costly action. The second behavioral indicator asks respondents to send a letter to their U.S. Senator, choosing from one of two form letters, or no letter. The inclusion of this indicator serves multiple purposes. Substantively, it helps us ascertain whether individual support for or opposition to U.S. ICC membership actually has implications for policymakers. Methodologically, this and the previous behavioral indicator help address one of the most salient criticisms against survey experiments, i.e., that responses are merely “cheap talk”. This is especially important when one is working with a subject pool (i.e., MTurk workers) that may have “satisficing” tendencies. There may be non-exemptionalist reasons for which participants may oppose U.S. membership in the ICC. While people may generally support the missions of international organizations, like the United Nations, they may question or doubt the effective implemen- tation of the organizations’ missions. I thus ask two supplementary questions—randomly assigned to appear pre- and post-frames—and use these to control for individuals with a baseline opposition to international organizations, irrespective of their purpose. I choose the United Nations, as it is a well-known international organization whose institutional mission is related to the ICC’s.

q1.value: Political attitude and Personality- the determinants of cultural and economical conservatism

q3.value: Based on current research, the study measures cultural and economic conservatism and how they are linked to Right-wing-authoritarianism (RWA), Social Dominance Orientation (SDO) and the personality, raised by the HEXACO model and the Dark Triad.

q4.value:
1.There is a relationship between conservatism and conscientiousness, openness and agreeablenes.
2.There is a relationship between cultural conservatism and the Dark Triad.
3. There is a relationship between cultural conservatism and RWA, and between economical conservatism and SDO.
4.There is a relationship between RWA and the Dark Triade.
5.There is a relationship between SDO and honesty-humility, openness and agreeablenes.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: The participants remain anonymous for the researcher. In the Informed Consent of the questionnaire the participants are told that the survey is a Master's thesis at the University of Vienna and is interested in the relationship between political attitude and personality . All answers are collected anonymously and cannot be traced back to individual persons.

question.value: The study is a cross-sectional, quantitative and multivariate Correlational survey study with undirected hypothesis. Dependent variables are RWA, SDO, the 6 personality traits from the HEXACO-Model and the three personality traits from the Dark Triade. The Undependent Variable is conservatism with the two levels of cultural and economical conservatism. It will be an Ad-hoc sample, which will be recruted in online groups and websites and in „real“ life by paper-pencil.

q9.value: There will be no randomisation as there will be no subdivided groups.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited in German-speaking area (Germany, Austria, Switzerland), through friends, relatives, social media groups (facebook), other websites and homepages, which deal with social political issues. Additionally participants will be recruited, who take part in through paper pencil in order to include also elderly people. Participants must be at least 18 years old. Participation is voluntary and will not be remunerated, but there will vouchers drawn by among all participants.

q13.value: The target sample size is at least 180 participants. I will attempt to recruit up to 300, assuming that not all will complete the necessary parts of the survey.

q14.value: No Power analysis is used. The survey is carried out within a fixed time of 03.2020 until 05.2020.

q15.value: The survey is carried out in the first run within three months (03.2020-05.2020). If the necessary sample size of minimum N= 180 is not reached, the study is carried out for another 3 months, no later than August 2020. After then the analysis will be started with the number of samples collected up to that point.

question.value: No manipulated variables

1. Cultural and economic conservatism are measured by the Economical and Cultural Conservative Scale (SECS, De Witte &  Duriez, 1990). It has 24 items with a 5-level Likert scale.
2. Rightwing authoritarianism is measured by the short version of the RWA scale (Altemayer, 1998) by Ingrid Zakrisson (2009). It consists of 15 Items with a 7-level Likert scale.
3. Social Dominance Orientation is measured by the SDO scale (Pratto et al., 1994), with 16 Items and a 7-level-Likert scale.
4. Personality is measured by the HEXACO-Personality-Inventar ((Lee & Ashton, 2009). It consists of 60 Items (10 Items per dimension) with a 5-level LIkert scale.
5. The Dark Triade (Psychopathy, Narcissm and Machiavellism) is measured by the short D3 (Paulhus & Williams, 2002) with 28 Items and a 5-level Likert scale.
The sum score of each construct and each person will be taken.

Two Multiple Hierarchical Regressions will be conducted with the cultural conservatism and economical conservatism as the criteria; and RWA, SDO, the personality traits from the HEXACO-model and the Dark Triade as the predictors. The Multiple Hierarchical Regression will be stepwise oriented, and based on the theory and literature SDO will be taken as the first, RWA as the second, the HEXACO-model as the third and the D3 as the fourth predictor.

q21.value:
Significance level at alpha = .05. KI= 95%, Effect sizes for correlations according to Cohen (1992) (small = 0.1, medium = 0.3, large = 0.5).
Effect strength for Multiple linear regression = R^2 (weak = 0.02, medium = 0.13, strong = 0.26)

q22.value: If some participants have filled in a part of the survey, which is sufficient enough to test a hypothesis, this data set is retained. If there are data, which consist of nonsense answers, or data with same rating scores in every Item, these data will be excluded. If outliers exist, the Regression will be conducted once with the outliers included and then exclusive the outliers, to check any differences in the results.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the tests or only a part of the survey, which is not sufficient enough to test a hypothesis, this subject will be removed from the analysis.

Van Hiel, A., Cornelis, I., Roets, A., & De Clercq, B. (2007). A comparison of various authoritarianism scales in Belgian Flanders. European Journal of Personality: Published for the European Association of Personality Psychology, 21(2), 149-168.
Zakrisson, I. (2005). Construction of a short version of the Right-Wing Authoritarianism (RWA) scale. Personality and individual differences, 39(5), 863-872.
registration_responses.q8.question: The study is a cross-sectional, quantitative and multivariate Correlational survey study with undirected hypothesis. Dependent variables are RWA, SDO, the 6 personality traits from the HEXACO-Model and the three personality traits from the Dark Triade. The Undependent Variable is conservatism with the two levels of cultural and economical conservatism. It will be an Ad-hoc sample, which will be recruted in online groups and websites and in „real“ life by paper-pencil.
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants will be recruited in German-speaking area (Germany, Austria, Switzerland), through friends, relatives, social media groups (facebook), other websites and homepages, which deal with social political issues. Additionally participants will be recruited, who take part in through paper pencil in order to include also elderly people. Participants must be at least 18 years old. Participation is voluntary and will not be remunerated, but there will vouchers drawn by among all participants.
registration_responses.q16.question: No manipulated variables
registration_responses.q17.question:
1. Cultural and economic conservatism are measured by the Economical and Cultural Conservative Scale (SECS, De Witte &  Duriez, 1990). It has 24 items with a 5-level Likert scale.
2. Rightwing authoritarianism is measured by the short version of the RWA scale (Altemayer, 1998) by Ingrid Zakrisson (2009). It consists of 15 Items with a 7-level Likert scale.
3. Social Dominance Orientation is measured by the SDO scale (Pratto et al., 1994), with 16 Items and a 7-level-Likert scale.
4. Personality is measured by the HEXACO-Personality-Inventar ((Lee & Ashton, 2009). It consists of 60 Items (10 Items per dimension) with a 5-level LIkert scale.
5. The Dark Triade (Psychopathy, Narcissm and Machiavellism) is measured by the short D3 (Paulhus & Williams, 2002) with 28 Items and a 5-level Likert scale.
registration_responses.q18.question: The sum score of each construct and each person will be taken.
registration_responses.q19.question: Two Multiple Hierarchical Regressions will be conducted with the cultural conservatism and economical conservatism as the criteria; and RWA, SDO, the personality traits from the HEXACO-model and the Dark Triade as the predictors. The Multiple Hierarchical Regression will be stepwise oriented, and based on the theory and literature SDO will be taken as the first, RWA as the second, the HEXACO-model as the third and the D3 as the fourth predictor.

attributes.title: Understanding the operationalisation and conceptualisation of 'marketing' in food and drink marketing research: a systematic scoping review of reviews

q1.value: Understanding the operationalisation and conceptualisation of 'marketing' in food and drink marketing research: a systematic scoping review of reviews

q2.value: Hannah Forde, Jean Adams, Martin White, Felix Greaves, Victoria Targett

q3.value: Marketing of food and drinks may have a negative influence on health, as substantial evidence has shown it to be more common for- and associated with- the purchasing and consumption of less healthy foods and drinks. As a result, marketing is increasingly subject to regulation. However, persistent limitations in these regulations coupled with competitive pressure to continually innovate marketing techniques, means a review of the current approach for generating evidence about food and drink marketing might inform and improve the development of future legislation. Published review studies and syntheses of primary evidence provide a rich source for understanding how food and drink marketing research has been generated and interpreted to date. To understand these issues, this protocol is for a scoping review of reviews to understand the conceptualisation and operationalisation of “marketing” in dietary public health research.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Blinding is not applicable to this study.

question.value: Five stages of the Arksey and O’Malley methodology underpin the scoping review process. In stage 1, the research questions were defined, following which the eligibility criteria and search strategy were outlined (stage 2). Stage 3 details the study selection process based on the identified eligibility criteria and in stage 4, a framework developed for this review will inform the extraction and charting of relevant information from the included literature. Results will be aggregated and summarised in stage 5, developing findings relevant for future dietary public health marketing research and associated regulations. Stage 6, stakeholder engagement, will entail presenting the results at conferences, disseminating to funders, and using social media. The study does not require ethical approval since it aims to synthesise information from existing publications.

question.value:
This scoping review of reviews will address the broad research question: “how is ‘marketing’ conceptualised and operationalised in dietary public health research?”. To answer this question, the review will aim to answer the following sub-questions:

Conceptualisation
•	What, if any, definition of marketing is employed in dietary public health literature?
•	How is “marketing” understood alongside related terms e.g. advertising?
•	How, if at all, is marketing activity described in relation to other industry behaviour?

Operationalisation
•	Are definitions of marketing consistently applied throughout studies?
•	What forms of marketing are more commonly studied?
•	What search terms are used to gather evidence and how do these correspond with the concepts under study?
•	Are any tools used to understand the evidence produced in the context of marketing in practice e.g. theory?

We will conduct title and abstract searches using a logic grid of terms in five databases: Embase (via Ovid), Medline (via Ovid), Cochrane Library, Web of Science, and PscyhINFO (via Ebscohost).  Terms in the logic grid relate to the eligibility criteria for literature to be included in the review. 

The eligibility criteria are: 
- Any author-defined review of published evidence, such as systematic review, meta-analysis, scoping review, evidence map, rapid review, literature review, evidence synthesis, narrative reviews, critical review, or equivalent.
- Concern any form of commercially-derived marketing [technique] e.g. promotion, product, placement, price…etc, across any possible medium e.g. internet, TV, retail environment.
- Concern any food/non-alcoholic drink related outcome or description e.g. consumption/purchasing behaviours, attitudes, cognitions. Mapping of the nature of marketing also eligible for inclusion.
- Must review literature in the explicit context of health.
- Any population.  
- Published in English Language.
- Published 2006 onwards, because that is when the first World Health Organisation review on food and drink marketing was published.
- Peer reviewed or grey literature included.

After the database search, a grey literature search will be conducted, as some of the grey literature may have already been captured in the first stage. The grey literature search will demand a different approach, in which specific websites will be purposively searched: Public Health England, Rudd centre, Cancer Research UK, Institute for Social Marketing, UK Health Forum, Obesity Alliance, Sustain, and Centre for Science in the Public Interest. These organisations have been selected because preliminary searches found them to be a rich source of potentially relevant data.  We may also search using a popular internet search engine (www.google.co.uk), as is common for grey information searches.

All review articles emerging from the searches will be retrieved, stored and de-duplicated in Covidence, a web-based software platform that streamlines the production of systematic reviews by supporting the review process. Covidence will also be used to coordinate activity across the review team. 

The titles and abstracts of remaining articles will be double-screened against the eligibility criteria (HF will screen all publications; double-screening will be divided equally across other members of the team). To ensure consistency across screeners, every member of the screening team will screen the same sample of publications (20) against the eligibility criteria, and will then meet to discuss any discrepancies and refine the inclusion/exclusion criteria as necessary. A cautious approach will be taken to including studies at this stage, with any uncertainty resulting in studies progressing to the next stage of selection; and the reasons for exclusion will be recorded. The screening team will meet again once the screening process has been completed, in order to resolve any discrepancies with the assistance of an arbitrator (most likely a member of the supervisory team) if necessary. 

For the studies remaining after title/abstract screening, HF will retrieve full-text versions and then screen them for inclusion. Again, this will be duplicated by members of the study team, with a similar process for resolving discrepancies. Study selection will be reported in a PRISMA-ScR flow diagram to permit reproducibility.
Not applicable to this study.

We will collect and sort key pieces of information from selected studies using a framework, which was developed during the scoping phase of this study. For each study, we will chart: 
1. Author(s)
2. Title
3. Year of publication
4. Publication source
5. Objectives of the review (summarise the stated objectives or research questions of the review)
6. Context (summarise where the study states that food/drink marketing is being explicitly reviewed in the context of health)
7. Type of review (state the type of review as defined by the author)
8. Funding source
CONCEPTUALISATION:
9. Marketing definitions (marketing definition(s) employed in the study)
10. Relationship with other terms (use of related terms throughout the manuscript e.g. advertising)
11. Relationship to industry behaviour (whether the marketing mediums/tools of focus are described in the context of other industry behaviour)
OPERATIONALISATION
12. Consistency in application of definition (examples from e.g. introduction, discussion)
13. Marketing medium(s)/tool(s) under review (detail the forms of marketing reviewed, even if not explicitly defined as marketing)
14. Search terms (search terms, inclusion and exclusion criteria that describe how evidence was gathered)
15. Tools for understanding (e.g. theory, could be a diagram)
16. Reviewer comments

The framework is based on the research sub-questions and similar to those employed elsewhere. The framework contains categories identified a priori to assess the full review articles that are selected in stage 3. This includes standard bibliographical information (e.g. title, authors, journal, year of publication), in addition to information relating to the research aims (e.g. use of marketing terminology).  We will also chart stated funding information about the articles, in order to track the potential for funding sources to introduce bias to the literature base.

As the majority of data required will be extracts of text, the framework and charted data will be stored on NVivo (https://www.qsrinternational.com/nvivo/home), as this software is appropriate for handling qualitative data. The framework will be piloted by HF and JA, who will chart a sample of literature [5 publications that passed full-text screening] in order to ensure there are adequate categories to fully explore the research questions within the sampled literature. Proposed amendments to the framework that emerge in this data charting will be discussed until consensus is reached between HF and JA. This should ensure inter-rater reliability in the review, by ensuring data extraction is consistent with the research objective and aims. HF will then be responsible for charting the data from each included review using the final data extraction framework. JA will review HF’s data charting and this will be discussed; if unresolvable discrepancies arise, another member of the study team will provide arbitration. As is common in scoping reviews, we will not make a quality assessment of the studies included as this is not pertinent to the research aims.
Not applicable to this study.
Not applicable to this study,

q25.value:
Scoping reviews specifically endeavour to aggregate findings and present an overview of a body of literature, yet challenges can arise in presenting a narrative account of this literature. To overcome some of these challenges, we will take guidance from the PRISMA-ScR reporting guidelines. Firstly, the study selection will be presented in a PRISMA-ScR flowchart. Then, the data will be collated and summarised in the data extraction framework. As most of the categories in the framework will contain text rather than numbers, a narrative will accompany the table in order to summarise the contexts of the table and address the specific research questions. This narrative may also entail comparing the data with the conceptualisation of marketing employed by marketers and marketing researchers. Not only will this narrative elucidate how marketing is operationalised in a sample of dietary public health marketing research, but it may also highlight under-researched areas suitable for future study.

The results of this review will be disseminated by open access publication to ensure it is available for a wide range of academics and research groups, and also policymakers developing regulation. The results will also be disseminated in various media, such as Twitter, and will contribute to the wider aim of the HF's research to understand the impact of soft drinks taxation on marketing. Standing relationships of the research team will support further dissemination (for example with Public Health England and the Economic and Social Research Council, who fund HF’s studentship).

Funding
HF, JA, and MW are supported by the Centre for Diet and Activity Research (CEDAR), a UKCRC Public Health Research Centre of Excellence. Funding from the British Heart Foundation, Cancer Research UK, Economic and Social Research Council, Medical Research Council, the National Institute for Health Research, and the Wellcome Trust, under the auspices of the UK Clinical Research Collaboration, is gratefully acknowledged (grant number MR/K023187/1). HF receives funding from the Economic and Social Research Council and Public Health England (PHE). FG and VT are employed by PHE. MW and JA hold honorary consultant in public health contracts with PHE. These funding sources have no direct role in the development of this protocol. Views expressed in this protocol are those of the authors and not necessarily those of the above named funders.

attributes.title: Meta-analysis
attributes.description:
Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection can progress to significant/advanced liver fibrosis, compensated cirrhosis, decompensated cirrhosis, or even hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), If left untreated. In advanced chronic liver disease (ACLD), a term that encompasses advanced liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, increasing portal pressure, as determined by hepatic venous pressure gradient,  becomes a key driver for disease progression of HBV infection. 
Increasing clinical evidence suggests that effective antiviral therapy with nucleos(t)ide analogues (NA) may not only attenuate hepatic necroinflammation, but may also induce liver fibrosis regression, even in patients who have already developed cirrhosis . Furthermore, NA treatment may also ameliorate portal hypertension . As a consequence, sustained viral suppression may improve clinical outcomes, namely, prevent first and further hepatic decompensation, as well as HCC development, thereby improving survival and quality of life. 
Thus, we want to perform a systematic review and meta-analysis to synthesize the currently available evidence on the impact of NA treatment on the related clinical outcomes in ACLD  patients.

q1.value: Impact of hepatitis B virus suppression on the course of advanced chronic liver disease: a Systematic review and meta-analysis

q2.value: jidong Jia, Lv tingting, yuanyuan Kong, Zhao lianhui, Hong You

q3.value:
Chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection can progress to significant/advanced liver fibrosis, compensated cirrhosis, decompensated cirrhosis, or even hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), If left untreated. In advanced chronic liver disease (ACLD), a term that encompasses advanced liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, increasing portal pressure, as determined by hepatic venous pressure gradient,  becomes a key driver for disease progression of HBV infection. 
Increasing clinical evidence suggests that effective antiviral therapy with nucleos(t)ide analogues (NA) may not only attenuate hepatic necroinflammation, but may also induce liver fibrosis regression, even in patients who have already developed cirrhosis . Furthermore, NA treatment may also ameliorate portal hypertension . As a consequence, sustained viral suppression may improve clinical outcomes, namely, prevent first and further hepatic decompensation, as well as HCC development, thereby improving survival and quality of life. 
Thus, we want to perform a systematic review and meta-analysis to synthesize the currently available evidence on the impact of NA treatment on the related clinical outcomes in ACLD  patients.

q4.value: The aim of our study is to compare the efficacy of different etiological therapies on the improvement of clinical outcomes among HBV related ACLD patients, such as Treated vs. Untreated, First-line drugs vs. Non First-line drugs, TDF vs. ETV, Combination therapy vs. Monotherapy, etc.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a Systematic review and Meta-analysis that will be performed with a random-effects model or fix effect model as appropriate.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
MEDLINE/PubMed, Embase, Web of Science/Web of Knowledge, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), as well as abstracts of major international hepatology meetings, i.e., American Association for the Study of the Liver Diseases (AASLD), The Liver Meeting and European Association for the Study of the Liver (EASL), and the International Liver Congress (ILC) were searched from 1995/01/01 to 2020/02/01.
Eligibility criteria: Clinical studies on antiviral therapies that were published after the first use of lamivudine were considered. Studies using interferon (IFN)-based regimens were not included, as virologic outcomes of these treatments are variable and not necessarily comparable to viral suppression achieved with NA, which are nowadays preferred over pegylated IFN in patients with ACLD, especially if complicated by portal hypertension. 
Exclusion  criteria: (I) Studies which only included non-ACLD patients or did not report information on the group of ACLD patients, unless this information is provided by the authors; (II) studies which did not report information on at least one of the outcomes of interest (liver fibrosis, portal hypertension, as well as related non-invasive surrogate parameters, varices, hepatic decompensation, or death). III Studies using interferon (IFN)-based regimens were not included.
Relevant information was extracted by four reviewers independently, and verified by two senior experts in case of controversy.
No response

Risk ratios (RR) or hazard ratios (HR) were measured for the development of clinical outcomes, including histological improvement, hepatic decompensations, variceal bleeding, ascites development, hepatic encephalopathy and death/liver translation.  Mean value and standard deviation were measured for MELD score/Child-Turcotte-Pugh score.

Pooled analysis was conducted to calculate the risk ratios (RR) or hazard ratio (HR) of regression of liver fibrosis, variceal bleeding, development of hepatic decompensation, HCC, death/liver translation. A random-effects model or fix effect model was used to calculate the aggregated results and their 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for effect size as appropriate. 
The improvement of MELD score/Child-Turcotte-Pugh score were expressed as a mean value and standard deviation and were pooled using weighted mean differences (WMD).
Begg’s test, Egger's test and Funnel plot were performed to evaluate publication bias. 
Review Manager Software version 5.3 (The Nordic Cochrane Centre, The Cochrane Collaboration, Copenhagen, Denmark) and Stata Software (version 13.0, Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA) were used for meta-analysis. P value <.05 was considered statistically significant.

q20.value: The origin data will be transformed when there is both numbers and proportions. In a subgroup, the data will be transformed into the same form as "n/total" , "HR" or "RR".

q21.value: The I² index was calculated to assess the among-studies’ heterogeneity and Cochrane Q-test was used to determine statistical significance. An I² value >50% or a P value <0.05 may be considered to represent substantial heterogeneity.

q22.value: Sensitivity analysis by the type of clinical events were performed in order to determine which factor was contributing to the between-study heterogeneity. Begg’s test, Egger's test and Funnel plot were performed to evaluate publication bias.

q23.value: If a required variable can not be calculated by other data/information in the included study, we will only analyze the available data.

registration_responses.q22: Sensitivity analysis by the type of clinical events were performed in order to determine which factor was contributing to the between-study heterogeneity. Begg’s test, Egger's test and Funnel plot were performed to evaluate publication bias.
registration_responses.q23: If a required variable can not be calculated by other data/information in the included study, we will only analyze the available data.
registration_responses.q8.question: This is a Systematic review and Meta-analysis that will be performed with a random-effects model or fix effect model as appropriate.
registration_responses.q12.question:
MEDLINE/PubMed, Embase, Web of Science/Web of Knowledge, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), as well as abstracts of major international hepatology meetings, i.e., American Association for the Study of the Liver Diseases (AASLD), The Liver Meeting and European Association for the Study of the Liver (EASL), and the International Liver Congress (ILC) were searched from 1995/01/01 to 2020/02/01.
Eligibility criteria: Clinical studies on antiviral therapies that were published after the first use of lamivudine were considered. Studies using interferon (IFN)-based regimens were not included, as virologic outcomes of these treatments are variable and not necessarily comparable to viral suppression achieved with NA, which are nowadays preferred over pegylated IFN in patients with ACLD, especially if complicated by portal hypertension. 
Exclusion  criteria: (I) Studies which only included non-ACLD patients or did not report information on the group of ACLD patients, unless this information is provided by the authors; (II) studies which did not report information on at least one of the outcomes of interest (liver fibrosis, portal hypertension, as well as related non-invasive surrogate parameters, varices, hepatic decompensation, or death). III Studies using interferon (IFN)-based regimens were not included.
Relevant information was extracted by four reviewers independently, and verified by two senior experts in case of controversy.
registration_responses.q16.question: No response
registration_responses.q17.question: Risk ratios (RR) or hazard ratios (HR) were measured for the development of clinical outcomes, including histological improvement, hepatic decompensations, variceal bleeding, ascites development, hepatic encephalopathy and death/liver translation.  Mean value and standard deviation were measured for MELD score/Child-Turcotte-Pugh score.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Pooled analysis was conducted to calculate the risk ratios (RR) or hazard ratio (HR) of regression of liver fibrosis, variceal bleeding, development of hepatic decompensation, HCC, death/liver translation. A random-effects model or fix effect model was used to calculate the aggregated results and their 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for effect size as appropriate. 
The improvement of MELD score/Child-Turcotte-Pugh score were expressed as a mean value and standard deviation and were pooled using weighted mean differences (WMD).
Begg’s test, Egger's test and Funnel plot were performed to evaluate publication bias. 
Review Manager Software version 5.3 (The Nordic Cochrane Centre, The Cochrane Collaboration, Copenhagen, Denmark) and Stata Software (version 13.0, Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA) were used for meta-analysis. P value <.05 was considered statistically significant.

attributes.title: Gratitude and Well-being in Adolescence
attributes.description: Secondary data analysis on a longitudinal study of positive youth development in adolescents. We are testing whether gratitude predicts increases in well-being over time and whether that effect is mediated by prosocial tendencies.

q1.value: What good is gratitude? Longitudinal models of gratitude and well-being in adolescence

q3.value: Over two decades of research demonstrates that gratitude is important for promoting individuals’ well-being. Importantly though, longitudinal methods are lacking. Further, less is known longitudinally among youth, seriously limiting the empirical picture of gratitude as a transformational behavior in human development. This is the purpose of this study. In a sample of adolescents from suburban areas, this study examines gratitude’s prediction of various aspects of well-being over 4 years. Students completed questionnaires in their classrooms as well as three months, six months, and four years later. Gratitude is conceptualized broadly as having a disposition and mood that enables positive responses for benefits and benefactors in life. Autoregressive panel models will be used to analyze longitudinal associations between gratitude and well-being outcomes, whether any associations are mediated by social integration and prosocial behavior, and whether individual differences in positive affect moderate any of gratitude’s longitudinal effects on well-being outcomes.

q4.value:
1) Gratitude will predict increases in well-being over time.
2) Increases in prosocial tendencies over time will mediate the longitudinal relationship between gratitude and well-being.
3) Positive affect will moderate the longitudinal indirect effect of gratitude on well-being through prosocial tendencies such that adolescents low in positive affect will have a stronger indirect effect.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: No blinding is involved in this study

question.value: The data used to the test the hypotheses come from an observational study without any variable manipulation. The study was longitudinal and included five timepoints; however, we will only be using four of them. Participants were adolescents who completed self-report surveys about their personality and functioning at multiple timepoints. We have published a previous manuscript from the study (https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17439760.2017.1402078).

q9.value: No randomization is involved in this study

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: We have cleaning and scoring the existing data as well as conducted analyses for a first manuscript (https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17439760.2017.1402078) that involves some of the same variables (e.g., gratitude, prosocial behavior, life satisfaction). Therefore, we are quite familiar with the data and variables we will be using (e.g., summary statistics). However, we have not tested the specific hypotheses for the present, second manuscript.

question.value: NA

q13.value: The baseline sample size is 566 participants. Attrition for complete cases from the first manuscript (https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17439760.2017.1402078) resulted in the following sample sizes at each timepoint: 3 months = 501, 6 months = 349, 4 years = 269. These numbers are based on variables used in our first manuscript with the data and thus may be slightly off for the present, second manuscript due to inclusion of additional variables.

question.value: No manipulated variables are involved in this study
The attached word document specifies which survey items are used to measure each variable.

data.name: Constructs, parcels, and items for gratitude and well-being paper_011220.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Constructs, parcels, and items for gratitude and well-being paper_011220.docx

question.value: Item parcels will be created by unweighted averaging of the items within each parcel. These parcels will then be used to construct latent factor measurement models within a broader SEM.

Structural equation modeling (SEM) will be conducted with the `lavaan` R package. Three separate types of models will be tested. The indirect effects of gratitude on increases in well-being mediated by increases in prosocial tendencies over time will be tested with the 1) total sample 2) multi-group model with two groups for low and high positive affect where all parameter estimates are free to vary across groups and 3) the same multi-group model where the mediation paths are fixed to be equal across groups. There are two prosocial tendency mediators: 1) social integration and 2) prosocial behaviors and there are eight well-being outcomes: 1) life satisfaction, 2) meaning in life, 3) hope, 4) depression, 5) negative affect, 6) positive affect, 7) happiness, 8) general well-being. This results in 3 types of models * 2 mediators * 8 outcomes = 48 different SEMs. Attached is a powerpoint file with the four different versions of the longitudinal mediation model that arise from not having all constructs measured at each timepoint.

Before any models are tested, the 2 mediators * 8 outcomes = 16 different measurement models will be created. The parcels from each construct will be used to create latent factors. Each construct * timepoint combination will have a single latent factor. For constructs measured at multiple timepoints, the parcel errors at one timepoint will be covaried with those at all other timepoints. All latent factors will be covaried with all other latent factors. At this point, the model fit of the measurement models will be evaluated. A balance will be sought between a desire for parsimonious models with a small amount of population misfit, and a desire for only small misspecifications that do not heavily bias the structural portion of the model. To quantify global model fit, the following (arbitrary) cutoffs will be used as guidelines: CFI < .90; TLI < .90; RMSEA > .10; SRMR > .10. To quantify local model fit, residual correlations will be investigated, and re-specification of the measurement models will be considered if any residual correlations are > |.20|.

Next, each construct measured at multiple timepoints will have its latent factors tested for measurement invariance. Only weak measurement invariance of the factor loadings will be investigated because only the covariance structure - not the mean structure - is relevant for the manuscript hypotheses. Any parcel whose standardized factor loadings differ by more than |.20| across timepoints will have its factor loadings free to vary, resulting in partial measurement invariance. Again, model fit of the measurement models will be evaluated with the same guidelines.

After the 16 measurement models are finalized, the structural model testing longitudinal mediation will be added to each. At this point, the three types of models mentioned above will be tested. The latent factor covariances representing a mediation path will be converted to latent factor regressions and any latent factor covariances with endogenous latent factors will be converted to covariances with the latent factor’s disturbance. Therefore, the structural models will be saturated as the goal is to test the significance and magnitude of the mediation paths rather than test whether certain paths are equal to 0. Similarly, we wish to capture change over time rather than test the adequacy of a first-order autoregressive structure. For the multi-group models, low and high positive affect will be determined by a median split of an unweighted average of the three T1 positive affect parcels.

For all models, the estimator will be full information maximum likelihood (FIML) to account for the missing data and standard errors will be computed via bootstrapping (including for the indirect effects). To increase the probability of meeting the missing at random (MAR) assumption behind FIML, 1-5 auxiliary variables will be added to each of the SEMs. These auxiliary variables will be those variables in the study dataset, but not already in the initial SEM, that are predictive of missingness at T3, T4, and T5 or are correlated with variables already in the initial SEM. The number of auxiliary variables will depend on how many variables in the study dataset are incrementally associated with missingness and initial model variables.

q20.value:
In addition to the unstandardized regression coefficients computed by the optimization algorithm, an unstandardized indirect effect and total effect will be calculated as post-estimation transformations. Unstandardized indirect effects will equal A-path unstandardized regression coefficient * B-path unstandardized regression coefficient. Unstandardized total effects will equal Unstandardized indirect effect + Cprime-path (i.e., direct effects are equal to Cprime-path unstandardized regression coefficients). The `lavaan` R package allows for bootstrapping on the post-estimation transformations; therefore, the standard errors of the unstandardized indirect effects and total effects will also be computed via bootstrapping.

Standardized versions of each effect size will also be calculated via post-estimation transformations. The standardized regression coefficients = unstandardized regression coefficient * standard deviation of the predictor / standard deviation of the outcome. The standardized indirect effect = standardized A-path * standardized B-path. The standardized total effect = standardized indirect effect + standardized Cprime-path. Again, the standard errors will be computed via bootstrapping within `lavaan`.

q21.value: Statistical inference will be based on null hypothesis significance testing (NHST) and the magnitude of standardized effect sizes. The Type I error rate used will be .05 and any standardized regression coefficients greater than .075 in magnitude will be deemed meaningful. The p-values of most interest will be those for the mediation paths. To determine the statistical significance of the indirect effects, 95% bootstrapped confidence intervals will be used. Statistical inference for the moderation will be based on the likelihood ratio test (LRT) comparing the multi-group model with mediation paths fixed vs. freed across low and high positive affect subsamples.

q22.value: All available data for a participant will be used.

q23.value: Participants must have observed data for at least 50% of the components (i.e., items) of the parcels, otherwise the score will be coded as missing. For example, if a participant responded to two of the three items in the Positive Affect parcels, their parcels would still scored for that participant. However, if the participant responded to one of the three items in the Positive Affect parcels, then their parcels would be coded as missing. Missing data at the parcel level will be handled by the FIML estimator within the SEM (see the Statistical Model section).

attributes.title: Gender Inequality
attributes.description: In this correlational study, we look at the relation between perceived sexism in society and feelings of exclusion.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

other.value:
Some exploratory analyses may be conducted, testing if the need threats mediate the relation between perceived sexism in society, and lower expectations of chances in the job market, and feelings of demotivation. We may also test if expectations of chances in the job market mediate the relation between perceived sexism and experienced demotivation.

In the results, we describe p-values equal or below 0.05 to be significant, between 0.05 and 0.10 to be marginally significant, and above 0.10 to be non-significant.

Because the hypothesized effects may rely on how ambitious participants are with regards to their career, we test this ambition among participants. As a check, we may also test if ambition changes with perceptions of sexism in society.

sample.value: Data will be collected from approximately 250 British female participants, with a university Bachelor degree or higher, between 18 and 50 years old.

analyses.value:
For all hypotheses, we will test the predicted relations with a correlation.

For H1, a simple correlation tests if perceptions of society as sexist correlates positively with feelings of exclusion from society.
For H2, a simple correlation tests if perceptions of society as sexist correlates positively with need threats.
For H3, a simple correlation tests if perceptions of society as sexist correlates positively with negative feelings.
For H4, a simple correlation tests if perceptions of society as sexist correlates negatively with expectations of success in the job market.
For H5, a simple correlation tests if perceptions of society as sexist correlates positively with demotivation in the job market.

outliers.value:
Participants will be excluded from the analyses if:

- They do not indicate they identify as female.
- They do not complete the full survey.

dependent.value:
All items are answered on a 7-point scale with 1 = Totally disagree, 7 = Totally agree, unless noted otherwise.

Sexism: 5 items, adapted from the modern sexism scale (Barreto & Ellemers, 2005; Swim, Aikin, Hall, & Hunter, 1995), measure how sexist women perceive society to be. "Discrimination against women is still a problem.", "Men and women have equal chances of achievement." (reversed), "The fact that few women hold high positions in society is due to discrimination.", "In British society, men and women are generally treated equally." (reversed), and "Women are often treated in a sexist manner.".

Exclusion: "As a woman, I am excluded by society”, and "As a woman, I am rejected by society".
Need threats: "As a woman, I do not really feel like I belong in society", and, reverse-scored "As a woman, I feel accepted in society" (belonging). Reverse-scored: "As a woman, I experience personal control over where I end up in society", and "As a woman, I have the feeling that others decide for me where I end up in society" (control). Reverse-scored: "Being a woman in this society makes me feel good about myself". and, "Being a woman in this society has a negative effect on my self-esteem" (self-esteem). "Being a woman, I feel invisible in society" and, reverse-scored, "Being a woman in this society gives me the feelings that my life is meaningful". All items are collapsed into one measure of need threats, if reliability allows.

Negative feelings: “My position as a woman in society makes me feel..”, “sad”, “angry”, “hurt”, “happy”, “elated”, “cheerful”, last three items reverse coded (adapted from Van Beest & Williams, 2006). All items are collapsed into one measure of 'feelings' if reliability allows.

Expectations of success: Participants are asked to "consider for a moment the highest position that you would like to hold in your working life. You may aspire to move up in the company you work in, or dream to hold some high-regarded position in society.
Below, please indicate the highest possible position that you would like to achieve." Participants answer this open ended question. Then, they are instructed to "think back on the highest possible position that you mentioned you would like to achieve, and indicate below to what extent you agree with the statements."
"As a woman, I think discrimination will not stand in my way of achieving this position.", and, reverse-coded, "Personally, I think that compared to an equally skilled male candidate, my chances of achieving this position are much smaller.". Both items are collapsed into one measure of expectation of success, if reliability allows.

Demotivation is measured with two questions: “As a woman, how do you feel about trying to acquire this position?" answer options 1 = Demotivated, 7 = Motivated, and 1 = Discouraged, 7 = Encouraged. Both items are reversed and collapsed into one measure of demotivation, if reliability allows.

Ambition: To get a sense of how ambitious participants in our sample are, one exploratory control question is asked: "In general, as how ambitious do you see yourself with regards to your career?".

conditions.value: This is a correlational study, with no conditions.

hypothesis.value:
In news media there is a lot of attention for sexism as the root of gender inequality, which confirms the occurrence of sexism. This contrasts the modern sexist belief that sexism is no longer a problem in society. Although the latter is seen as a sexist belief that is harmful for women's position in society, the current research tests if confirming sexism may also have negative effects, because women start to believe that being discriminated against for them is the norm. In this study, we test whether female participants who believe to a greater extent that women are being discriminated against in society, may also feel more excluded from society, have lower need fulfilment, more negative feelings, perceive their chances of success to be lower, and are less motivated in the job market.

H1: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the more excluded from society they feel.
H2: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the more threats to their fundamental needs they experience.
H3: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the more negative they feel.
H4: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the lower they perceive their chances to find a desirable job.
H5: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the less motivated they are to acquire a desirable job.

(reversed), and "Women are often treated in a sexist manner.".

Exclusion: "As a woman, I am excluded by society”, and "As a woman, I am rejected by society".
Need threats: "As a woman, I do not really feel like I belong in society", and, reverse-scored "As a woman, I feel accepted in society" (belonging). Reverse-scored: "As a woman, I experience personal control over where I end up in society", and "As a woman, I have the feeling that others decide for me where I end up in society" (control). Reverse-scored: "Being a woman in this society makes me feel good about myself". and, "Being a woman in this society has a negative effect on my self-esteem" (self-esteem). "Being a woman, I feel invisible in society" and, reverse-scored, "Being a woman in this society gives me the feelings that my life is meaningful". All items are collapsed into one measure of need threats, if reliability allows.

Negative feelings: “My position as a woman in society makes me feel..”, “sad”, “angry”, “hurt”, “happy”, “elated”, “cheerful”, last three items reverse coded (adapted from Van Beest & Williams, 2006). All items are collapsed into one measure of 'feelings' if reliability allows.

Expectations of success: Participants are asked to "consider for a moment the highest position that you would like to hold in your working life. You may aspire to move up in the company you work in, or dream to hold some high-regarded position in society.
Below, please indicate the highest possible position that you would like to achieve." Participants answer this open ended question. Then, they are instructed to "think back on the highest possible position that you mentioned you would like to achieve, and indicate below to what extent you agree with the statements."
"As a woman, I think discrimination will not stand in my way of achieving this position.", and, reverse-coded, "Personally, I think that compared to an equally skilled male candidate, my chances of achieving this position are much smaller.". Both items are collapsed into one measure of expectation of success, if reliability allows.

Demotivation is measured with two questions: “As a woman, how do you feel about trying to acquire this position?" answer options 1 = Demotivated, 7 = Motivated, and 1 = Discouraged, 7 = Encouraged. Both items are reversed and collapsed into one measure of demotivation, if reliability allows.

Ambition: To get a sense of how ambitious participants in our sample are, one exploratory control question is asked: "In general, as how ambitious do you see yourself with regards to your career?".
registration_responses.conditions: This is a correlational study, with no conditions.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
In news media there is a lot of attention for sexism as the root of gender inequality, which confirms the occurrence of sexism. This contrasts the modern sexist belief that sexism is no longer a problem in society. Although the latter is seen as a sexist belief that is harmful for women's position in society, the current research tests if confirming sexism may also have negative effects, because women start to believe that being discriminated against for them is the norm. In this study, we test whether female participants who believe to a greater extent that women are being discriminated against in society, may also feel more excluded from society, have lower need fulfilment, more negative feelings, perceive their chances of success to be lower, and are less motivated in the job market.

H1: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the more excluded from society they feel.
H2: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the more threats to their fundamental needs they experience.
H3: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the more negative they feel.
H4: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the lower they perceive their chances to find a desirable job.
H5: We predict that the more women perceive society to be sexist, the less motivated they are to acquire a desirable job.

attributes.title: Replicating Experiment 1a of "Morality constrains the default representation of what is possible (2017)"

item1.value: We aim to replicate the claim that there are differences in default and deliberate forms of modal cognition when making possibility judgments of different kinds of events.

item2.value: The results of experiment 1a claim that the default possibility representations are constrained by prescriptive norms for moral events. This normative assertion needs to be tested since it has implications not just for moral philosophy but also for moral decision-making field.

item5.value: The sample size is 93 (From Phi φ = 0.3587, power = 0.80, and alpha = 0.05).

item11.value: All stimuli used are from the original study. Further, since time constraints are crucial in this experiment, we have strictly replicated the timings of the stimulus presentation.

item12.value: The experimenters will not be with the participants during data collection.

item13.value: Assignment of participants to 2 groups (reflective and speeded) is randomized. Hence, the experimenters will not have any influence on it whatsoever.

item14.value: Experimenters involved are aware of the hypotheses.

item16.value: From Phi φ = 0.3587 for the interaction effect, power = 0.80, and alpha = 0.05, the sample size comes to be 93. We are pre-registering the sample size to be 100, considering potential data loss.

item26.value: Trials on which participants do not respond will be excluded from the analyses. Subsequently, each participant’s average response time (excluding outlier responses defined as >6,000 ms) will be computed. All data from a participant will be dropped if a participant’s average response time is lower than 800 ms in the speeded condition or lower than 1,000 ms in the reflective condition. Additionally, data from all trials on which a response is given in less than 500 ms will be dropped, as will data from reflective trials on which the response is given in less than 1,500 ms.

item27.value: In this replication, we are following the exact analysis plan of the original study. A series of linear mixed-effects models will be conducted to test whether participants’ judgments of the possibility of the five different kinds of events differed across time pressure/delay conditions. Chisquare tests will be used to investigate the effect of speeded judgments, that of event-type, as well as the interaction of both. Further, the effect of speeded and deliberate judgments on different events will be conducted using z-tests.

item28.value: We define a successful replication as getting at least half of the effect size (Phi φ = 0.3587) for the interaction term while maintaining the direction of the effect.

attributes.title: Social Reinforcement of Moral Outrage in Online Social Networks

q2.value: William J. Brady, Killian McLoughlin, Tuan Nguyen, Molly Crockett

q3.value: Testing in a behavioral paradigm that people readily infer norms about outrage expression in online social networks, and how this influences reinforcement learning. This study intends to test this these processes that we see evidence for in our Twitter sample.

q4.value:
We hypothesize that people rely on two different types of learning depending on what information they have: reinforcement learning (trial-and-error learning) when they must rely on (likes/shares) to learn from or (2) efficient learning based on the communication of an expected behavior (inferring social norms) when such information can guide them.

Thus, we predict that when people must rely on social feedback (when norm does not guide them as in the view neutral norm condition), they will select Twitter messages that maximize the feedback amount relatively more and show a greater learning curve. However, when participants observe tweets that give them information about the norms of communication in their environment (view outrage condition), they will select the tweets that match the norm with relatively less sensitivity to the social feedback reward trajectory. In other words, the view neutral norm condition should show a significantly greater learning rate over trials than the view outrage norm condition.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
In this study, participants are randomly assigned to one of two conditions: "View Outrage Norm", "View Neutral Norm" condition. Participants view 12 tweets that were ostensibly posted by the new social network they will be embedded in for the learning task. 

In the View Outrage Norm condition, participants will be exposed to tweets, 75% of which contain outrage, where the outrage tweets also contain higher social feedback values than the 25% neutral tweets.

In the View Neutral Norm condition, participants will be exposed to 100% non-outrage tweets, with higher social feedback values being randomly assigned to the tweets.

All participants will then participate in the same reinforcement learning task where they view pairs of tweets (1 outrage, 1 neutral) and choose which tweet to send to their network with the goal of maximizing their total likes. Stimulus pairs are randomized, reward trajectories have the following structure: 80% of the time an outrage tweets selection leads to the delivery of likes drawing from a distribution with a larger mean (the "high feedback distribution). 20% of the time choosing an outrage tweet will deliver a feedback amount drawn from the "low feedback" distribution. The opposite is true for neutral tweets. This design adds noise to the learning to ensure it is not too easy.

q9.value: Using simple randomization, participants will be randomly assigned to condition once they enter the study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will recruit participants via Prolific, and we will recruit only liberal-learning participants because our tweet stim only express political views aligned with liberal values.

We will also recruit social media users, since our goal is to simulate a Twitter environment in our task to support the analyses we performed in our Twitter sample.

q13.value: We will collect 120 participants and each participants will have 30 observations (trials).

q14.value: We will collect 120 participants, which was determined by the required sample size to achieve 95% power to detect differences in slope of the learning effect over trials among the conditions. We used SIMR, an R package for power analysis for GLMMs.

q15.value: We will only collect the 120 participants planned from the power analysis.

question.value: We manipulate whether participants view an outrage norm network or view a neutral norm network.
We will measure the binary choice of whether to "share" an outrage message or a neutral message for each of the 30 trials.
n/a
We will use a generalized linear mixed model with a log link function to model participants' selection of outrage on a trial-by-trial basis across the learning task.

q21.value: We will reject the null for p < .05

q22.value:
We will remove participants who are not liberal-learning according to self-report measure of ideology.

We will remove participants who did not spend more than 30 seconds viewing the tweets in their network during the norm manipulation.

We will remove participants who exhibit homogeneous choices across all 30 trials of the learning task. In other words, if a participants just clicked the tweet to the left for all trials, or clicked the tweet to the right for all trials.

q23.value: Participants who do not complete the full learning task will be removed.

q24.value: We will report any analyzes not preregistered in this form as exploratory. This may include examining if learning is moderated by self-reported social media use.
